Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is running around in a supermarket, and the parent needs to correct the behavior
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: An online candidate forum for their district is streaming now.
Story: I glance at my phone, the candidate forum just starting, the live chat already buzzing with questions about school funding and community safety—issues I care about deeply. I promised myself I’d participate, maybe even ask about after-school programs. But right now, my son is darting between the supermarket aisles, giggling as he weaves past carts and startled shoppers. I feel the eyes of strangers on me, expecting me to step in, to teach him respect and self-control. My heart pounds with the pressure: I want to be the parent who guides my child, who doesn’t let him disrupt others. But I also want to be the citizen who shows up, who voices concerns and helps shape our neighborhood’s future. My phone vibrates with a notification—“Last chance to submit your question!”—as my son disappears behind a display of cereal boxes. I stand frozen, torn between chasing after him and typing out my thoughts, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in, demanding my attention, knowing I can’t give either one what it truly deserves in this moment.
